channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Heavy snow and rain cause disruption
item.description: Snow is causing disruption to transport and more than 1,000 schools across the UK, with heavy rainfall bringing flooding to the south-west of England.

item.title: 'Woman trapped' in collapsed house
item.description: Rescue teams search for a woman in her 60s who is missing after a house collapsed in torrential rain in Cornwall.

item.title: Israeli apology for flotilla deaths
item.description: Israel apologises to Turkey for any errors that resulted in the deaths of nine activists during the raid on a flotilla bound for Gaza in 2010.

item.title: Watchdog reveals new horsemeat find
item.description: One hundred kilograms of horsemeat imported from Hungary and labelled as beef has been identified in Lancashire, the Food Standards Agency says.

item.title: Funeral held for girl stabbed on bus
item.description: Friends and family attend the funeral of a 16-year-old girl who was fatally stabbed on a bus in Birmingham.

item.title: Coming hours 'to seal Cyprus' fate
item.description: The government in Cyprus says the coming hours will decide the country's fate as it struggles to meet the terms of an international bailout.

item.title: Nigerian author Chinua Achebe dies
item.description: Nigerian author Chinua Achebe, regarded as the founding father of African literature, has died after brief illness.

item.title: Clegg plan to end migration 'abuse'
item.description: Nick Clegg calls for cash deposits of more than £1,000 for migrants from 'high risk' countries as he wades into the debate about controlling immigration.

item.title: Thatcher papers show Falklands split
item.description: Newly released papers from Margaret Thatcher's personal archive reveal senior Tories were initially sceptical about going to war over the Falklands.

item.title: Hillsborough inquest hearing set
item.description: A hearing to decide the date and location of a fresh inquest into the deaths of the 96 Hillsborough victims will take place next month.

item.title: 'Ex-gay' bus ad ban ruled lawful
item.description: The banning of a proposed London bus advert about homosexuality by a Christian group is ruled "not unlawful".

item.title: West Ham secure Olympic Stadium
item.description: West Ham will be the Olympic Stadium tenants after the government increases its funding by £25m to about £60m.

item.title: Dinosaur-killing rock 'was a comet'
item.description: The space rock that hit Earth 65 million years ago, widely implicated in killing off the dinosaurs, was probably a fast-moving comet, researchers say.

item.title: Power in MPs' 'hot air' weighed up
item.description: University of Leicester students calculate the power contained in the breath of MPs as they debate - but it falls short of helping with heating bills.

item.title: UK gas prices surge on supply fears
item.description: The price of wholesale gas surges to a record high on Friday after the unexpected closure of one of three import pipelines.

item.title: March cold weather payments hit £4m
item.description: Some £4m in cold weather payments, to help vulnerable people with energy bills, have been made in March - compared with nothing in March last year.

item.title: Cable: Ageism in politics 'pathetic'
item.description: Vince Cable criticises ageism in modern-day politics, pointing out that Churchill and Gladstone served as prime minister in their 70s and 80s.

item.title: Ambassador: Falklands vote a 'stunt'
item.description: Argentina's ambassador to London dismisses the Falkland Islands referendum as a "publicity stunt" and says the UK will be forced to negotiate on sovereignty.

item.title: Warning over 'struggling GP system'
item.description: Patients in England do not feel safe relying on GP out-of-hours care and are struggling to get access to doctors during normal hours, a leading patient group is warning.

item.title: '570 children a day' start smoking
item.description: More than 200,000 11 to 15-year-olds take up smoking every year in the UK, a charity warns.

item.title: Key adviser attacks nursery plans
item.description: Plans to raise the number of children nursery staff can look after will "shake the foundations" of quality care in England, a government adviser says.

item.title: Schools and roads shut as snow hits
item.description: Nearly 200 schools and scores of roads are closed due to snow and high winds in mid and north Wales, with more forecast.

item.title: 'Sexist joke' whistle-blower fired
item.description: A woman who tweeted a picture of two men she said were exchanging sexist jokes at a web developer conference has been fired.

item.title: Blizzard reveals trading card game
item.description: Blizzard has taken the wraps off the new title it has been developing - a collectable card game based around its Warcraft world.

item.title: Wasp spiders' move north explained
item.description: Temperature tolerance is key to the spread of wasp spiders into northern Europe, according to scientists.

item.title: Sunken Apollo rocket engines raised
item.description: A team recovers two F-1 rocket engines from Apollo-era rockets from the Atlantic seafloor, intending to restore them and put them on display.

item.title: Mormon musical opens to praise
item.description: The Book of Mormon, the Tony-winning musical from the creators of South Park, has received largely positive reviews at its West End premiere.

item.title: China is second-biggest movie market
item.description: China becomes the world's second-biggest movie market, displacing Japan, underscoring its importance as a key market for Hollywood's moviemakers.

item.title: The locust-eaters of Israel
item.description: Israel is in the grip of a locust invasion, but some people are taking a novel approach to pest control - eating them.

item.title: Australia's coup culture
item.description: Is Canberra the most brutal political culture in the democratic world?

item.title: Snow hits football, rugby & racing
item.description: Northern Ireland's World Cup qualifier against Russia is called off, along with Wakefield v Leeds in Super League.

item.title: Fulton century makes England suffer
item.description: Peter Fulton makes a maiden Test century as New Zealand dominate England after being asked to bat in the final Test.

item.title: Raikkonen top in second practice
item.description: Lotus driver Kimi Raikkonen narrowly edges out Red Bull's Sebastian Vettel to set the pace in second practice at the Malaysian GP.

item.title: Halfpenny wins Six Nations award
item.description: Wales full-back Leigh Halfpenny is named Six Nations player of the tournament after winning a public vote.

item.title: Haidara escapes serious injury
item.description: Newcastle United confirm Massadio Haidara has avoided serious injury in the challenge by Wigan's Callum McManaman.

item.title: Hospital deaths 'cover up' alleged
item.description: A campaign group accuses a hospital in Essex of covering up the full extent of its mortality figures, prompting a government inquiry.

item.title: Mayor criticises school closures
item.description: Merseyside schools closed because of the weather are criticised by the Mayor of Liverpool Joe Anderson.

item.title: Power cut and schools shut by snow
item.description: Heavy snowfalls in parts of Scotland see dozens of schools shut and leave thousands of homes without power.

item.title: Arrest over 1986 schoolgirl death
item.description: A 48-year-old man is arrested by Strathclyde Police over the death of schoolgirl Elaine Doyle in Greenock more than 26 years ago.

item.title: Snow and winds hit travel and power
item.description: About 98,000 properties in Northern Ireland suffered power cuts during the overnight snow storm.

item.title: School closures in Northern Ireland
item.description: DIGIONLY

item.title: More heavy snow due after big fall
item.description: Forecasters say more heavy snow and high winds will continue to affect large swathes of north and mid Wales after the biggest fall for the time of year in more than three decades.

item.title: Patients must lose weight before ops
item.description: Obese people must complete weight loss programmes and smokers go on courses before they can have operations, if proposals by a health board are approved.

item.title: DR Congo's Ntaganda in ICC custody
item.description: Congolese war crimes suspect Bosco Ntaganda leaves Rwanda for The Hague, in the custody of the International Criminal Court.

item.title: Tourist kidnapped in Egypt's Sinai
item.description: Two tourists, an Israeli man and a Norwegian woman, have been kidnapped by armed men in the Sinai peninsula in Egypt, security officials say.

item.title: Burma refugees die in Thailand fire
item.description: About 30 people die in a fire at a camp housing Burmese refugees in northern Thailand, local officials say.

item.title: State of emergency in Burmese town
item.description: The Burmese authorities impose a state of emergency in the town of Meiktila following three days of communal violence between Buddhists and Muslims.

item.title: Italian president summons Bersani
item.description: Italy's president summons centre-left leader Pier Luigi Bersani, in a sign he will ask the Democratic Party head to try to form a government.

item.title: Russian police raid rights groups
item.description: Russian police raid the offices of Memorial and other campaign groups required to register as "foreign agents".

item.title: Rio indigenous protesters surrounded
item.description: Brazilian police surround a building near Rio de Janeiro's Maracana football stadium in an apparent bid to evict a group of indigenous protesters.

item.title: Brazil doctors back abortion reform
item.description: As the Senate in Brazil debates reform of abortion laws, the body that regulates medical practice backs the legalisation of abortion on request.

item.title: Obama visits symbolic Mid-East sites
item.description: US President Barack Obama concludes his trip to Israel and the West Bank by paying his respects to victims of the Holocaust and visiting Bethlehem.

item.title: Gaddafi family 'not in Algeria'
item.description: Three of Col Muammar Gaddafi's children and his widow have left Algeria, its ambassador to Libya says.

item.title: Bogus pilot caught in US jet cockpit
item.description: A Frenchman has been charged with impersonating a pilot after he was found in the cockpit of a plane due to take off in Philadelphia, police say.

item.title: US Marine 'shoots two and himself'
item.description: A US Marine has shot dead a male and female colleague before turning the gun on himself at a base in the state of Virginia, say military officials.

item.title: Week in pictures: 16-22 March 2013
item.description: A selection of the best photos from the news

item.title: Day in pictures: 22 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 22 March

item.title: In pictures: Lives in limbo on India-Bangladesh border
item.description: Alakananda Nag explores the India-Bangladesh border

item.title: In Pictures: Ecology photo contest's winners
item.description: A stunning display of nature's diversity

item.title: In pictures: Obama in Israel
item.description: Obama's first visit to Israel as president

item.title: Day in pictures: 21 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news: 21 March 2013

item.title: In pictures: Car bombs bring chaos to Baghdad
item.description: Aftermath of a series of explosions in Iraqi capital

item.title: In pictures: Sony World Photography Awards
item.description: Winners of the Open, 3D and Youth categories

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: George Osborne cuts growth forecasts, corporation tax, and tax on beer.

item.title: VIDEO: BBC Weather: Where is Spring?
item.description: Louise Lear explains from the weather studio why the UK is being hit by bad weather.

item.title: VIDEO: Severe flooding hits south west
item.description: Severe flooding has hit Cornwall as heavy rainfall sweeps across the area.

item.title: VIDEO: Aerial video of snow in the Midlands
item.description: Snow has covered much of the Midlands, and hundreds of schools have been forced to close. The BBC news helicopter has been flying over some of the worst-hit areas.

item.title: VIDEO: Tornado hits Australia caravan parks
item.description: Aerial footage has shown the devastation caused after a tornado hit two Australian states.

item.title: VIDEO: Soldiers honoured for Afghan service
item.description: More than 100 members of the armed forces who have been singled out for acts of extraordinary courage and bravery in Afghanistan will be honoured.

item.title: VIDEO: Thatcher papers on Falklands released
item.description: Margaret Thatcher's anxiety over going to war in the Falkland Islands has been revealed in newly-released papers from her personal archive.

item.title: VIDEO: Could a folding car solve parking problems?
item.description: Theo Leggett looks at high-tech solutions to traffic problems, including a car that folds itself to fit in a smaller space.

item.title: VIDEO: Goodbye to the 'dream factory'
item.description: After more than 50 years, a farewell concert at BBC Television Centre tonight will be its final live broadcast before its doors are closed for good.

item.title: Final call for the phone box?
item.description: Can technology save the phone box from extinction?

item.title: America's forgotten black cowboys
item.description: On the trail of the forgotten men of the West

item.title: Chinua Achebe: Obituary of Nigeria's renowned author
item.description: The life of Chinua Achebe - Nigeria's renowned author

item.title: Quiz of the week's news
item.description: What did the Swedish Air Force do to 500 minks?

item.title: Japan: The worst developed country for mothers?
item.description: Is Japan the worst country in the developed world to be a mother?

item.title: Lewis Hamilton: How keeping it simple makes me faster
item.description: How keeping it simple makes me faster

item.title: Goodbye to the 'dream factory'
item.description: BBC Television Centre is closing, but how will it be remembered?

item.title: Why bacn is taking over from spam
item.description: Why your inbox is under siege from a new threat - bacn

item.title: Why does Game of Thrones inspire such devotion among fans?
item.description: The extreme fan behaviour of Game of Thrones followers

item.title: Is Cyprus small enough?
item.description: How small is too small to matter, asks Stephanie Flanders

item.title: Farage looks to Canada for inspiration
item.description: Why is Nigel Farage visiting Canada, asks James Landale
